column3: “You lot are getting off easily,” he had told us at Confirmation class. “Had you been unfortunate enough to have lived in about 1550, in the time of King Edward the Sixth—who died at the age of fifteen…younger than you, there, Ted Pullymore…yes, you, Ted…and who died coughing up green, black, and pink matter, leading some to believe he had been poisoned—you’d have had to sit still three times longer than we do nowadays. In those days, the Gospel reading for Palm Sunday combined Matthew chapters 26 and 27, and would have lasted somewhere between twenty minutes and half an hour.
